context: Gaddafi briefly studied <a0_0><a5_0><a11_0>History<a11_0/><a5_0/> at the <a10_0>University of Libya<a10_0/> in Benghazi<a0_0/>, before dropping out <a6_0>to join the military<a6_0/>. Despite his police record, in 1963 he began training <a2_0>at the <a12_0>Royal Military Academy<a2_0/>, Benghazi<a12_0/>, alongside several like-minded friends from Misrata. The armed forces offered <a3_0>the only opportunity for upward social mobility for underprivileged Libyans, and <a7_0>Gaddafi recognised it as a potential instrument of political change<a7_0/><a3_0/>. Under Idris, Libya's armed forces were trained by <a8_0>the British military<a8_0/>; this angered <a1_0>Gaddafi, who viewed the British as <a14_0>imperialists<a14_0/><a1_0/>, and accordingly he refused to learn English and was rude to the <a13_0>British<a13_0/> officers, ultimately failing his exams. British trainers reported him for insubordination and abusive behaviour, stating their suspicion that he was involved in <a4_0><a9_0>the assassination of the military academy's commander in 1963<a9_0/><a4_0/>. Such reports were ignored and Gaddafi quickly progressed through the course.
